:Not to be confused with the evolutionary concept of a [[transitional fossil]].



In genetics, a 'transition' is a point mutation that changes a purine nucleotide
to another purine (A â G) or a pyrimidine nucleotide to another pyrimidine (C â
T). Approximately two out of three single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are
transitions.

Transitions can be caused by oxidative deamination and tautomerization. [ht-
tp://www.mun.ca/biochem/courses/3107/Topics/Mutations.html Mutations & Mutagenesis ] Although there are twice as many possible
transversions, transitions appear more often in genomes, possibly due to the
molecular mechanisms that generate them.

5-Methylcytosine is more prone to transition than unmethylated cytosine, due to
spontaneous deamination. This mechanism is important because it dictates the rarity of CpG islands.
